55.heading: Virginia.
55.title: Last Exit Before Toll
55.author: written by Neal Shaffer ; pencilled by Christopher Mitten ; lettering & digital tones by Dawn Pietrusko.
notes: 1 v. : ill. ; 21 cm.

"Charles Pierce has reached a dead end. He's got a good job and his family loves him, but he wanders through life as if he were barely there. On a business road trip, his car breaks down, stranding him in a small town in rural Virginia. While at first he greets his circumstances with irritation, Charles slowly begins to realize that this accident may be the luckiest thing that ever happened to him. His disappearance may just be his chance at a new life, and the down-to-earth waitress from the local diner might just be his second opportunity for love. That is, if the past doesn't catch up with him first."

127.heading: Virtual Views.
127.title: "Sinkha"
127.author: by Marco Patrito and Virtual Views, S
127.appears_in: N.C., and Strata, Inc., dba Mojave. p. 50-112 in Heavy Metal Special ; v. 10, no. 2 (Fall 1996).
notes: Summary: Hyleyn, a girl born in the city of Thalissar on the planet Ogon, wants to leave and see the universe. She gets herself taken aboard the Sinkha spaceship Darcron. At the same time both the humans and the Sinkha make disturbing discoveries about the nature of Thalissar: it was not built as a city by humans, but rather found and moved into a thousand years earlier. Thalissar is inhabited by a sleeping monster called Kahaltar. Kahaltar can tamper with the reality others perceive in order to protect itself, and uses Hyleyn as a human shield. The monster is defeated, but Hyleyn nearly dies and will need a new body generated for her.

150.heading: Virtuoso Cartoonists.
150.title: Historic Virtuoso Cartoonists
150.author: exhibition curator: Lucy Shelton Caswell ; catalogue designer: Frank Pauer.

publication info.publisher: Ohio State University Cartoon Research Library

notes: "2001 Festival of Cartoon Art."

"This catalogue is published as part of the 2001 Festival of Carton Art to accompany the exhibition Historic Virtuoso Cartoonists from August 26 through September 30, 2001 at the Columbus Recreation and Parks Department Cultural Arts Center."

Biographical sketches of Thomas Nast, Joseph Keppler, Frederick Burr Opper, Richard Felton Outcault, Winsor McCay, Nell Brinkley, George Herriman, Edwina Dumm, Rube Goldberg, Milton Caniff, Walt Kelly, Charles M. Schulz, Willard Mullin, James Thurber, Oliver Harrington, Art Young, Jay 'Ding' Darling, Rollin Kirby, and Jeff MacNelly.

Brief essays on cartoon virtuosity, with contributor notes for each, by Shelly Armitage, Kenneth Stacey Baker, Daniel Bolsinger, John Canemaker, N.C. Christopher Couch, Bill Crouch, Will Eisner, Roger A. Fischer, Thierry Groensteen, R.C. Harvey, M. Thomas Inge, Jim Ivey, Michael Kahn, Gene Kannenberg Jr., Amy Lago, John A. Lent, Jack Loftis, Patrick McDonnell, Toni Mendez, Roy Paul Nelson, Richard D. Olson, Charles Press, Trina Robbins, Lee Salem, Rob Stolzer, Steve Thompson, Brian Walker, Mort Walker, Judith Wechsler, Richard Samuel West, Bruce Wheltle, Malcolm Whyte, Glenda Winders, and Art Wood.

170.heading: Viruses.
170.title: Eden : It's an Endless World
170.author: Hiroki Endo ; translation, Kumar Sivasubramanian ; lettering, Steve Dutro.
notes: "Parental advisory, explicit content" label on cover.

"Eden is both a brilliant love song to the post-apocalyptic survival genre and an exploration on humanity's role in the natural order. When a large portion of civilization is wiped out by a brutal new virus, those who aren't immune are either severely crippled or live only with cybernetically enhanced or entirely mechanical bodies. Taking advantage of a world in chaos, the paramilitary Propater forces topple the United Nations and seek global domination. In this cutthroat, cyberpunk future, Elijah, a young boy on a personal quest, travels with an artificially intelligent combat robot through a pitiless, futuristic landscape."
